name: NHL 25 Defensive Zone Strategy Tree
description: Canonical defensive zone strategy tree using ONLY NHL 25 in-game options: Collapsing, Staggered, and Tight Point. Each option includes strengths, weaknesses, when to use it, and matchup tags.

notes: All defensive strategy names must match NHL 25 UI EXACTLY.
Matchup outputs must only use these three strategy options.
Defensive Strategy combines with Defensive Pressure and Trap/Forecheck settings to build full gameplans.

Collapsing.label: Collapsing
Collapsing.description: Defensive zone setup that collapses coverage toward the slot and crease, forcing opponents to the outside and protecting high-danger areas.
strengths: Excellent at protecting the middle and net-front.
Best for holding leads or facing teams that attack inside lanes.
weaknesses: Allows open point shots and perimeter puck movement.
Can lead to long offensive zone time for the opponent.
Less effective vs teams with strong point shots and screens.

recommended_usage.protecting_lead: Primary option, especially late in games.
recommended_usage.tied_game: Good vs slot-focused or heavy net-front opponents.
recommended_usage.trailing: Use sparingly; may stall transition offense.

Staggered.label: Staggered
Staggered.description: Balanced defensive zone setup that staggers defenders between the slot and the points, aiming to disrupt both low cycle and high point shots.
strengths: Balanced coverage between slot and point.
Good vs teams that cycle low then go high to the point.
Helps cut off seam passes and high-to-low attacks.
weaknesses: Not as strong as Collapsing at pure net-front protection.
Not as aggressive as Tight Point at pressuring shooters.
Can feel 'middle of the road' if opponent has a clear strength.

recommended_usage.protecting_lead: Solid in early/mid-game, especially vs cycle teams.
recommended_usage.tied_game: Strong default choice for most opponents.
recommended_usage.trailing: Still viable; does not over-expose defensively.

Tight Point.label: Tight Point
Tight Point.description: Aggressive defensive zone setup that focuses on pressuring the point and shooters up high, reducing time and space for long-range shots.
strengths: Best vs teams with dangerous point shots or bomb shooters.
Reduces time for one-timers and slapshots from the blue line.
Can generate turnovers at the blue line for transition chances.
weaknesses: Opens up more space down low and around the crease.
Can be vulnerable to quick plays into the slot.
Riskier when defending a lead, especially late.

recommended_usage.protecting_lead: Use carefully; mostly avoid late in games.
recommended_usage.trailing: Good option if you need turnovers and fast breaks.

notes: Use Collapsing in the final 5 minutes to protect the net.
Use Staggered earlier in the game if the opponent runs a heavy low-high cycle.
Staggered is the default balanced choice.
Collapsing is preferred vs teams that relentlessly attack the crease.
Staggered keeps you safe but flexible.
Tight Point can create turnovers and fast breaks but risks slot chances.

opponent_style_based.why: Best at protecting the crease and slot from constant pressure.
Matches up well against low cycle into point shots.
Takes away time and space from shooters up high.

defensive_pressure.note: Defensive Strategy works together with Defensive Pressure. For example, 'Collapsing + Protect Net' is a full turtle, while 'Staggered + Contain Puck' is a balanced setup.
